question.title: How to throw an Exception when your method signature doesn't allow to throw Exception?

node.contents: You are testing something that is impossible to happen. Why?

astNode.text: You are testing something that is impossible to happen. Why?

node.contents:
I tried to mock soap response using LogicalHandler
<logicalmessagecontext>
 . The handleMessage(LogicalMessageContext context) doesn't declare throws Exception. But all the exception throws by the soap end point are subclass of Exceptions. I need to throw those exception to mock my service response.
</logicalmessagecontext>

</logicalmessagecontext>

node.contents: See my edit in case you're interested.

node.contents: Why you couldn't throw Unchecked exception? I can't understand what you were trying to do. What kind of test framework are you using? You can catch unchecked exceptions normally in your tests.

astNode.text: Why you couldn't throw Unchecked exception? I can't understand what you were trying to do. What kind of test framework are you using? You can catch unchecked exceptions normally in your tests.

node.contents: I have a method like this:

astNode.text: I have a method like this:

node.contents: I want to throw an exception inside getSomething. The compiler will not allow me to do that because my method doesn't allow Exception to be thrown in there. But I need to throw a subclass of Exception for my testing (I can't throw Unchecked exception). This is clearly a hack but I need it for my testing. I tried EasyMock but it doesn't allow me to do that either. Any ideas how to do that?

astNode.text: I want to throw an exception inside getSomething. The compiler will not allow me to do that because my method doesn't allow Exception to be thrown in there. But I need to throw a subclass of Exception for my testing (I can't throw Unchecked exception). This is clearly a hack but I need it for my testing. I tried EasyMock but it doesn't allow me to do that either. Any ideas how to do that?

node.contents: @PaulBellora you could always play around with the `Class::newInstance()` method, that can will throw anything the ctor does

astNode.text: @PaulBellora you could always play around with the `Class::newInstance()` method, that can will throw anything the ctor does

node.contents: @Demetri `(E)e` is an unchecked cast, meaning the JVM cannot fail fast if it's wrong. After type erasure the method is indistinguishable from `private static void throwAny(Throwable e) throws Throwable { throw e; }`.

astNode.text: @Demetri `(E)e` is an unchecked cast, meaning the JVM cannot fail fast if it's wrong. After type erasure the method is indistinguishable from `private static void throwAny(Throwable e) throws Throwable { throw e; }`.

node.contents: @PaulBellora Why doesn't the first example result in `ClassCastException` at runtime?

astNode.text: @PaulBellora Why doesn't the first example result in `ClassCastException` at runtime?

node.contents: Method 1:

astNode.text: Method 1:

node.contents: This post by Alexey Ragozin describes how to use a generics trick to throw an undeclared checked exception. From that post:

astNode.text: This post by Alexey Ragozin describes how to use a generics trick to throw an undeclared checked exception. From that post:

elements.contents: public class AnyThrow { public static void throwUnchecked(Throwable e) { AnyThrow.<RuntimeException>throwAny(e); } @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") private static <E extends Throwable> void throwAny(Throwable e) throws E { throw (E)e; } }

units.rawText: public class AnyThrow { public static void throwUnchecked(Throwable e) { AnyThrow<RuntimeException>throwAny(e); } @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") private static <E extends Throwable> void throwAny(Throwable e) throws E { throw (E)e; } }

node.contents: The trick relies on throwUnchecked "lying" to the compiler that the type E is RuntimeException with its call to throwAny. Since throwAny is declared as throws E, the compiler thinks that particular call can just throw RuntimeException. Of course, the trick is made possible by throwAny arbitrarily declaring E and blindly casting to it, allowing the caller to decide what its argument is cast to - terrible design when coding sanely. At runtime, E is erased and has no meaning.

astNode.text: The trick relies on throwUnchecked "lying" to the compiler that the type E is RuntimeException with its call to throwAny. Since throwAny is declared as throws E, the compiler thinks that particular call can just throw RuntimeException. Of course, the trick is made possible by throwAny arbitrarily declaring E and blindly casting to it, allowing the caller to decide what its argument is cast to - terrible design when coding sanely. At runtime, E is erased and has no meaning.

node.contents: As you noted, doing such a thing is a huge hack and you should document its use very well.

astNode.text: As you noted, doing such a thing is a huge hack and you should document its use very well.

node.contents: Method 2:

astNode.text: Method 2:

node.contents: You can also use sun.misc.Unsafe to this end. First you must implement a method that uses reflection to return that class's instance:

astNode.text: You can also use sun.misc.Unsafe to this end. First you must implement a method that uses reflection to return that class's instance:

elements.contents: private static Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field theUnsafeField = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); theUnsafeField.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe)theUnsafeField.get(null); } catch (NoSuchFieldException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } catch (IllegalAccessException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } }

units.rawText: private static Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field theUnsafeField = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); theUnsafeField.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe)theUnsafeField.get(null); } catch (NoSuchFieldException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } catch (IllegalAccessException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } }

node.contents: This is necessary as calling Unsafe.getUnsafe() will typically throw a SecurityException. Once you have the instance of Unsafe you can put its terrifying capabilities to use:

astNode.text: This is necessary as calling Unsafe.getUnsafe() will typically throw a SecurityException. Once you have the instance of Unsafe you can put its terrifying capabilities to use:

node.contents: Credit goes to this answer on the post Interesting uses of sun.misc.Unsafe. I thought I'd mention this for completeness but it's probably better just to use the trick above instead of allowing Unsafe into your code.

astNode.text: Credit goes to this answer on the post Interesting uses of sun.misc.Unsafe. I thought I'd mention this for completeness but it's probably better just to use the trick above instead of allowing Unsafe into your code.

node.contents: In this case you would use @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") and once again document very fiercely. Again, I prefer the first trick for its (relative) cleanliness.

node.contents: I am sorry for not being clear. I need to throw a subclass of java.lang.Exception (checked exception).

astNode.text: I am sorry for not being clear. I need to throw a subclass of java.lang.Exception (checked exception).

node.contents: @SeanNguyen RuntimeException is a subclass of Exception. It's just a special case in Java where you don't need to declare that it'll be thrown.

astNode.text: @SeanNguyen RuntimeException is a subclass of Exception. It's just a special case in Java where you don't need to declare that it'll be thrown.

node.contents: Sorry, not very clear again. I need to throw checked exception that is subsclass of Exception. I can't throw RuntimeException.

astNode.text: Sorry, not very clear again. I need to throw checked exception that is subsclass of Exception. I can't throw RuntimeException.

node.contents: @SeanNguyen: please tell us why you need to throw a checked exception.

astNode.text: @SeanNguyen: please tell us why you need to throw a checked exception.

node.contents: Java has two kinds of exceptions, checked and unchecked. You must declare checked exceptions, but you don't have to declare unchecked exceptions.

astNode.text: Java has two kinds of exceptions, checked and unchecked. You must declare checked exceptions, but you don't have to declare unchecked exceptions.

node.contents: RuntimeException is the basic unchecked exception, so you can throw that without declaring it.

astNode.text: RuntimeException is the basic unchecked exception, so you can throw that without declaring it.

elements.contents: public void getSomething(){ throw new RuntimeException("I don't have to be declared in the method header!"); }

node.valueRep: "I don't have to be declared in the method header!"

units.rawText: public void getSomething(){ throw new RuntimeException("I don't have to be declared in the method header!"); }

node.contents: As a side note, you probably don't want to throw a raw RuntimeException, but subclass it to something more specific to your needs. Any subclass of RuntimeException will be unchecked as well.

astNode.text: As a side note, you probably don't want to throw a raw RuntimeException, but subclass it to something more specific to your needs. Any subclass of RuntimeException will be unchecked as well.

node.contents: I don't know what you were trying to do. You could just throw an unchecked exception inside your method and then test using JUnit like in my example below.

astNode.text: I don't know what you were trying to do. You could just throw an unchecked exception inside your method and then test using JUnit like in my example below.

elements.contents: public void getSomething() { throw new RuntimeException(); }

units.rawText: public void getSomething() { throw new RuntimeException(); }

node.contents: JUnit 4 test example:

astNode.text: JUnit 4 test example:

elements.contents: @Test public void testGetSomething() { try { getSomething(); fail("Expecting RuntimeException!"); } catch (Exception e) { Logger.getLogger("test").info("Exception was caught: " + e.getClass()); } }

units.rawText: @Test public void testGetSomething() { try { getSomething(); fail("Expecting RuntimeException!"); } catch (Exception e) { Logger.getLogger("test").info("Exception was caught: "+ e.getClass()); } }

node.contents: I need to throw a subclass of Exception or Checked exception not RuntimeException.

astNode.text: I need to throw a subclass of Exception or Checked exception not RuntimeException.

node.contents: @SeanNguyen: If you need to throw a checked exception you need to declare it. There is no way around that.

astNode.text: @SeanNguyen: If you need to throw a checked exception you need to declare it. There is no way around that.

node.contents: RuntimeException is a subclass of Exception as you can see in the link provided by Keppil. So a subclass of RuntimeException is a subclass of Exception.

astNode.text: RuntimeException is a subclass of Exception as you can see in the link provided by Keppil. So a subclass of RuntimeException is a subclass of Exception.

node.contents: If your method getSomthing() throws a RuntimeException (or a subclass), then your test can catch the Exception. `getSomething() { throw RuntimeException("Foobar"); } ... @Test testIt() { try { getSomething(); } catch (Exception e) { e.printStacktrace(); }`

astNode.text: If your method getSomthing() throws a RuntimeException (or a subclass), then your test can catch the Exception. `getSomething() { throw RuntimeException("Foobar"); } ... @Test testIt() { try { getSomething(); } catch (Exception e) { e.printStacktrace(); }`

node.contents: THe problem is that I can't modify the signature of getSomething().

astNode.text: THe problem is that I can't modify the signature of getSomething().

node.contents: You can still throw an Unchecked exception even if none is declared.

astNode.text: You can still throw an Unchecked exception even if none is declared.

node.contents: You can read more about it in the Java Tutorials - How to Throw Exceptions.

astNode.text: You can read more about it in the Java Tutorials - How to Throw Exceptions.

node.contents: `RuntTimeExcepton` -- The smallest form of subatomic exception known to man.

astNode.text: `RuntTimeExcepton` -- The smallest form of subatomic exception known to man.

node.contents: It is not possible to throw a checked exception without declaring it. An unchecked exception (one that extends RuntimeException) must be used here, e.g.:

astNode.text: It is not possible to throw a checked exception without declaring it. An unchecked exception (one that extends RuntimeException) must be used here, e.g.:

elements.contents: public void getSomething(){ throw new IllegalStateException("An exception occurred!"); }

units.rawText: public void getSomething(){ throw new IllegalStateException("An exception occurred!"); }
